channel.title: RSC Bank Organization
channel.description:
What do you guys think would be the best approach to achieve this via the client itself? Or if none, where could i get started by using a website approach?
- Jerry

item.title: RSC Bank Organization
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:21, topic:544671"][quote author=Zlacki link=topic=663545.msg4438631#msg4438631 date=1405836212]

whats the point then :\

Exercise in futility; learning for the sake of it.
[/quote]
No, that is not an acceptable reason.[/quote]
This is the point I was trying to make. When reading other peoples opinions on how to communicate with something (incl. computers) in a turing complete manner, there will not always be an explanation that is acceptable. That is all I was saying–there are MANY a case where I see Java features being used unnecessarily, as do I in pretty much every language but Scheme(almost any dialect/implementation but Racket I’d say), and C(I’m unaware of a standardized version that this occurs in often).
In server daemons designed to synchronize specific things, it is often simpler to do these things in the same thread. Otherwise you’ll need to explicitly state to the computer Be aware of this and await a change,'' or similar pathology. A specific opposite of this comes to mind on a project I am working on currently in C99. I am utilizing SDL for easy cross-platform support of input, graphics, and audio. It provides me with fine-grained control over what gets executed, how it is executed, etc, while being compiled to a small native code binary for the target platform. It provides simplicity in this sense, while also providing all the means to my end. I never would have done something like this in Java, for the simple reason that it is almost always done for you in Java. You then lose the so-stated fine-grained control over execution. As CodeForFame stated, synchronizing everything is not acceptable as it is not needed for everything and is often simpler not to and involves lessboilerplate’’ code to work as expected on target machine.

Read full topic

item.title: RSC Bank Organization
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

^ Yeah.

You’ve got to do it in an intelligent and considered manner, and that really requires a fundamental understanding of concurrency and the happens-before relationship between memory access by different threads.

For what it’s worth, the synchronized keyword (i.e., using an object’s monitor lock) performs well when there’s little or no contention for the resource. In RSC servers, where there’s strict separation of packet handling and issuing world state packets to clients, it will often be the case that contention levels are low for all but the most sought after resources.

Read full topic

item.title: RSC Bank Organization
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:18, topic:544671"][quote author=imthenull link=topic=663545.msg4438336#msg4438336 date=1405791686]
are there any instances where moparclassic uses multiple threads other than for networking?
[/quote]
nope.[/quote]You’re wrong.

[quote="-Nothing, post:16, topic:544671"][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=663545.msg4436491#msg4436491 date=1405218607]
The current version is thread safe; I’d love to see this done with the Java version. Most of the methods in the original version are only a few lines, to make them thread safe, you’d need to add a few more to each, as they’re not using atomic operations.
[/quote]
Are you speaking of this?

items.synchronized {

Here you go.

synchronized (items) {

thread saef.[/quote]Just synchronizing everything is not acceptable…

Read full topic
